Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Effects of Alloy Concentration on the Tribocorrosion Resistance of Al-TM Supersaturated Solid Solutions
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Tribocorrosion is a material degradation process caused by the combined effects of wear and corrosion. It is a research area that emerged recently, driven by increased demand for wear- and corrosion-resistant materials from biomedical implants, nuclear power generation, marine and offshore industries, etc. The complexity of tribocorrosion lies in the fact that the chemical and mechanical attacks act synergistically to cause accelerated failure. The synergetic effect is most prominent for passive metals, such as stainless steels, titanium and aluminum alloys, which rely on the presence of a thin surface oxide film (passive film) as a protective barrier against corrosion. When mechanical wear takes place during corrosion, the passive film can be locally destroyed, with the ensuing depassivation leading to rapid corrosion and early component failure. This research seeks to offer insight concerning the degradation mechanisms during tribocorrosion of passive metals using experiments and modeling. The obtained results can lead to the development of new tribocorrosion resistant alloys and coatings with enhanced durability. Research opportunities and a mentorship program are created for undergraduate students and under-represented minorities. Relevant core undergraduate courses are updated to include tribocorrosion-related topics. The outreach program features hands-on demonstrations for girls in elementary and middle schools from Pinellas County, Florida, to stimulate their interest in STEM fields. Published and promoted videos demonstrating the physical concepts related to this research are on popular social media platforms to educate a broad and diverse audience about tribocorrosion.


TECHNICAL DETAILS: Al exhibits excellent corrosion resistance but poor scratch resistance, which greatly limits its potential usage in industrial applications where mechanical contact and corrosive environment coexist. Recent studies from our group demonstrates that alloying Al with a transition metal (TM) in supersaturated solid solution has the potential of simultaneously increasing the wear resistance of Al alloys as well as the protectiveness of the passive layer, thus improving the overall tribocorrosion resistance. This research project is directed towards identifying how alloy concentration affects deformation and degradation during tribocorrosion and is centered on a comprehensive study that integrates material processing, characterization, tribocorrosion testing, and theoretical modeling. The proposed processing technique produces materials with various alloy concentrations while minimizing crystallographic texture and residual stress effects. Materials are characterized site-specifically to evaluate the microstructural modifications induced by different degradation mechanisms during tribocorrosion, including wear and corrosion and their synergistic and stochastic aspects. The specific technical objectives include (1) establishment of the alloy concentration/tribocorrosion resistance relationship for Al-TMs, (2) determination of whether an optimum alloy concentration exists for the best tribocorrosion resistance, and (3) investigation of whether (and how) in-service conditions (e.g., applied load, sliding speed) and corrosion conditions influence the tribocorrosion resistance. The obtained results help establish better guidelines for the application of metals in harsh environments and service conditions. The findings also serve to improve design principles for new tribocorrosion-resistant Al alloys, the use of which presents great potential for increasing the sustainability of global energy consumption.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF CAREER research program has generated new understanding on the deformation and degradation mechanisms of aluminum (Al) alloys under simultaneous wear and corrosion attack (e.g. tribocorrosion) using experiments, atomic-scale characterization and modelling. Historically, a clear understanding of the atomic scale mechanism for tribocorrosion in Al alloys is lacking due to the lack of understanding of the composition, structure, and property of the metal surface and its interaction with the environment, which challenges the design of strong and corrosion-resistant alloys. To solve this grant challenge, this research combined materials synthesis, atomistic characterization via transmission electron microscopy and atom probe tomography to characterize the tribocorroded and passivated surfaces of model Al-Mn alloy systems with various alloying concentrations. Based on such atomic-scale characterization and modeling results, a new theory of controlling corrosion of concentrated Al alloys via selective solute dissolution was developed, where it is shown that the addition of a non-passive element (Mn) could enhance the corrosion resistance of a passive element (Al) without participating in the surface oxidation process. The selective dissolution of the non-passive element at the surface promotes the formation of a thinner yet more protective oxide layer at the metal surface for enhanced corrosion protection.  During tribocorrosion, it was found that the alloying concentration not only affects the pure wear and corrosion response, but also their synergy. Specifically, in the case of Al-Mn alloys, a positive wear-corrosion synergy was identified, where the trapping of abrasive wear debris with high Al2O3 content from passive film led to corrosion-accelerated wear, and wear-induced depassivation on the wear track led to wear-accelerated corrosion. The latter of the two were found to depend strongly on testing parameters such as sliding frequency, which in term affects the repassivation kinetics during wear. Finally, the experimental results were used to develop and validate a multiphysics finite element-based model for predicting tribocorrosion behavior of metals by accounting for wear, corrosion, and their synergy. Tribocorrosion rate maps were generated to predict the total material loss based on material inputs such key mechanical and electrochemical properties, which is applicable for performance prediction for Al alloys and passive metals in general.  

For broader impacts, the developed understanding has led to new alloy design strategies and performance prediction tools for robust, high performance materials used under extreme conditions with combined mechanical and chemical attack at the surface. Such materials have critical applications in areas such as aerospace and marine industries, nuclear systems, microelectronics, batteries, and biomedical devices, etc. In addition, a comprehensive education and outreach program was developed at the University of South Florida and Virginia Tech to improve the participation of females and underrepresented minority students in STEM fields.  Hands-on demonstrations and lab demos related to materials research have been performed to local K-12 students and teachers. Research opportunities have been provided to both undergraduate and graduate students at the two institutions. Educational videos have been published on YouTube to engage and educate an even broader audience in STEM. These videos include topics such as (1) How does copper surface kill Covid19? (2) How to model a 2D heat transfer problem using COMSOL multiphysics? (3) How to perform potentiodynamic polarization tests, etc. These videos provide both theory explanation and demonstration of protocols, which greatly benefit new researchers in the field.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/23/2021
Modified by: Wenjun Cai
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This NSF CAREER research program has generated new understanding on the deformation and degradation mechanisms of aluminum (Al) alloys under simultaneous wear and corrosion attack (e.g. tribocorrosion) using experiments, atomic-scale characterization and modelling. Historically, a clear understanding of the atomic scale mechanism for tribocorrosion in Al alloys is lacking due to the lack of understanding of the composition, structure, and property of the metal surface and its interaction with the environment, which challenges the design of strong and corrosion-resistant alloys. To solve this grant challenge, this research combined materials synthesis, atomistic characterization via transmission electron microscopy and atom probe tomography to characterize the tribocorroded and passivated surfaces of model Al-Mn alloy systems with various alloying concentrations. Based on such atomic-scale characterization and modeling results, a new theory of controlling corrosion of concentrated Al alloys via selective solute dissolution was developed, where it is shown that the addition of a non-passive element (Mn) could enhance the corrosion resistance of a passive element (Al) without participating in the surface oxidation process. The selective dissolution of the non-passive element at the surface promotes the formation of a thinner yet more protective oxide layer at the metal surface for enhanced corrosion protection. During tribocorrosion, it was found that the alloying concentration not only affects the pure wear and corrosion response, but also their synergy. Specifically, in the case of Al-Mn alloys, a positive wear-corrosion synergy was identified, where the trapping of abrasive wear debris with high Al2O3 content from passive film led to corrosion-accelerated wear, and wear-induced depassivation on the wear track led to wear-accelerated corrosion. Tribocorrosion rate maps were generated to predict the total material loss based on material inputs such key mechanical and electrochemical properties, which is applicable for performance prediction for Al alloys and passive metals in general. For broader impacts, the developed understanding has led to new alloy design strategies and performance prediction tools for robust, high performance materials used under extreme conditions with combined mechanical and chemical attack at the surface. Such materials have critical applications in areas such as aerospace and marine industries, nuclear systems, microelectronics, batteries, and biomedical devices, etc. In addition, a comprehensive education and outreach program was developed at the University of South Florida and Virginia Tech to improve the participation of females and underrepresented minority students in STEM fields. Hands-on demonstrations and lab demos related to materials research have been performed to local K-12 students and teachers. Research opportunities have been provided to both undergraduate and graduate students at the two institutions. Educational videos have been published on YouTube to engage and educate an even broader audience in STEM. These videos include topics such as (1) How does copper surface kill Covid19? (2) How to model a 2D heat transfer problem using COMSOL multiphysics? (3) How to perform potentiodynamic polarization tests, etc. These videos provide both theory explanation and demonstration of protocols, which greatly benefit new researchers in the field.
